parallel.translation[0].definitions[0].d: two lines, paths etc that are parallel to each other are the same distance apart along their whole length
parallel.translation[0].definitions[0].e: Lines AB and CD are parallel.
Take the road running parallel to the main road just after the village.
She was travelling parallel to her previous route.
The railway is parallel with the canal.
parallel.translation[0].definitions[1].d: similar and happening at the same time
parallel.translation[0].definitions[1].e: Social changes in Britain are matched by parallel trends in some other countries.
parallel.translation[1].definitions[0].d: a relationship or similarity between two things, especially things that exist or happen in different places or at different times
parallel.translation[1].definitions[0].e: books that attempt to draw parallels between brains and computers
Entering the world of fine art, she found many parallels with the world of fashion.
There are many parallels between Yeats and the Romantic poets.
parallel.translation[1].definitions[1].d: an imaginary line drawn on a map of the Earth, that is parallel to the equator
parallel.translation[2].definitions[0].d: if one thing parallels another, they happen at the same time or are similar, and seem to be related
parallel.translation[2].definitions[0].e: The rise in greenhouse gases parallels the reduction in the ozone layer.
His career parallels that of his father.
parallel.translation[3].definitions[0].d: parallel goods, imports etc are sold avoiding the DISTRIBUTION CHANNELs (=ways of making goods available to the public) approved by the makers
parallel.translation[3].definitions[0].e: Luxury brands manufacturers are angry about the sale of parallel goods in supermarkets.
parallel.translation[3].definitions[1].d: involving more than one computer operation happening at the same time
